===Etymology 1===
"To stand": A Northern Chinese word attested since the 9-10th centuries. Displaced earlier {{zh-l|立}} in most modern northern Chinese varieties.

====Definitions====
{{zh-hanzi}}

# to [[stand]]
#: {{zh-x|站起來|'''stand''' up}}
# to [[stop]], to [[halt]]
# {{lb|zh|figurative}} to take a firm [[stance]]; to [[uphold]] the stand

=====Synonyms=====
{{zh-dial}}

===Etymology 2===
Generally considered to be a Mongolian influence in the {{w|Yuan Dynasty}} – an abbreviation of {{zh-l|站赤|post stations during the Yuan Dynasty}}, from {{der|zh|xng|ᠵᠠᠮᠴᠢ||post station}} (> {{cog|mn|замч||guide; cicerone}}), a derivative of {{der|zh|xng|ᠵᠠᠮ||way, path}} (> {{cog|mn|зам}}).

Mongolian ''ǰam'' is undoubtedly cognate with {{cog|trk-pro|*jam||post station}} (> {{cog|tr|yam}}; ~ {{cog|ru|ям}}) with the same meaning; see {{w|Yam (route)}}. Starostin considers the Turkic form a descendant of {{cog|tut-pro|*ńi̯àmi||trace}} and related to Proto-Mongolian *''ǯim'' ("path, trace"; > {{cog|mn|ᠵᠢᠮ}} / {{l|mn|жим}}). Also compare {{cog|tr|yamçı||post rider}}, {{cog|ru|ямщи́к||drive, coachman}}.

There is no scholarly consensus regarding the direction of borrowing. Generally it is believed that Turkic ''jam'' and Chinese ''zhàn'' are loanwords from Mongolian ''ǰam'', however some (e.g. Tuymebayev in Казахско-монгольские лексические параллели) believe the directionality is reversed (i.e. Chinese "to stand > stand > station" → Middle Mongolian → Turkic → Russian). Whatever the etymology, what is apparent is that the word ''jam'' has been around for a long time and was used by Central Asians to designate a key postal relay station or official.

In Chinese, this word has been competing with the native equivalent {{zh-l|*驛|tr=yì|post station}} since its introduction. Mongol-ruled Yuan Dynasty saw the profusion of use of ''zhàn'', which was deliberately suppressed in the succeeding {{w|Ming Dynasty}} in favour of ''yì''. Both were used in the subsequent {{w|Qing Dynasty}}, with ''zhàn'' eventually predominating in the modern times, being used to render the sense of "station" in modern concepts, such as "train station". Other Sinosphere countries show preference variations too: Vietnamese uses {{lang|zh|站}} ({{m|vi|trạm}}), whereas Japanese and Korean still use {{lang|zh|驛}} for "station" (Japanese {{ja-l|駅|えき|eki}}, Korean {{ko-l|역|驛}}).
